questions.explanation: Subtracting from the argument t-3 delays (right-shifts) the signal. Think of it as the signal 'waiting' 3 units before starting. Adding to the argument would advance (left-shift) the signal.
Multiplying the argument by 2 compresses the signal horizontally by factor 2. Events happen twice as fast. To compress by a, use x(at) where a>1. To stretch, use a<1.
Replacing t with -t reflects the signal about the vertical axis (t=0). Past becomes future and vice versa. This is called time reversal or folding. The signal plays backwards.

questions.prompt: For x(2t-4), in what order should operations be applied?
questions.explanation: Rewrite as x(2(t-2)). First scale by 2 (compress), then shift by 2 (not 4!). The order matters: scale-then-shift uses the shift value divided by the scale factor.
Negating the entire function inverts the amplitude—positive values become negative and vice versa. This is reflection about the horizontal axis (t-axis). Not to be confused with time reversal x(-t).

questions.prompt: If x(t) has duration 4s, x(t/2) has duration:
questions.explanation: Dividing t by 2 means x(t/2) = x(0.5t). With a<1, the signal stretches. Duration multiplies by 1/a = 2. The signal becomes slower and takes twice as long. Everything happens at half speed.
This combines amplitude scaling by 2 and time shifting right by 1. The signal is delayed by 1 unit AND made twice as tall. Multiple transformations can be applied in sequence.
Rewrite as x(-(t-3)). First reverse x(-t), then shift right by 3. Alternatively: shift left by 3 to get x(t+3), then reverse to get x(-t+3) = x(3-t). Both approaches work.
Even signals are symmetric about t=0. Reflecting gives the same signal. Examples: cos(t), t², constants. Odd signals satisfy x(t) = -x(-t). Any signal can be decomposed into even and odd parts.

questions.prompt: If x[n] exists only for n≥0, what is x[-n] for n≥0?
questions.explanation: x[-n] evaluates x at -n. For n≥0, we're looking at x at non-positive indices. If x[n]=0 for n<0 (causal), then x[-n]=0 for n>0. The signal is flipped about n=0.
